de.dfki.lt.hfc

Class RuleStore

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.dfki.lt.hfc.RuleStore

  • public final class RuleStore
extends java.lang.Object
    a rule consists of an antecedent and a consequent; both antecedent and consequent are represented as a sequence of tuples, interpreted conjunctively; each tuple element is either a URI, an XSD atom, or a variable (new!) interpreted locally within the scope of the rule; blank nodes are not allowed in a rule, but can, of course, be generated through RHS-only free variables; note: blank nodes are clearly allowed in ground tuples, i.e., facts, which are matched against tuples in the antecedent of a rule; textually, a rule is encoded as an extension of the N-Triples syntax, where each tuple both in antecedent and consequent position must occupy a single line in the text file; antecedent and consequent are separated by "->" (again in a single line); a rule starts with a rule name (single line) and ends with an _empty_ line; comments are lines starting with the '#' character; comments are NOT allowed _inside_ a rule definition; a priority equals 0 switches off the rule this rule extension of N-Triples is called RDL for Rule (or Rewrite) Description Language ::= [] [] [action] ::= "$" ^+ ::= "&priority" ::= { }^+ ::= {"->" | "-->" | "=>" | |==>"} ::= { }^+ ::= "@test" { }^* ::= "@action" { }^* ::= "!=" { | | } | ^+ { | | }^* ::= = ^+ { | | }^* ::= "?"^+ ::= { | | }^+ ::= "<" ^+ ">" ::= "\"" "\"" ["@" | "^^" ] ::= any character, incl. whitespaces, numbers, even '\"' ::= any NON-whitespace character ::= any positive integer, including 0 note that the EBNF of RDL requires that the antecedent and consequent take at least _one_ tuple; so neither an empty antecedent (fact) nor an empty consequent (query) is possible note that fresh new individuals are generated by using _unbounded_ variables on the RHS of a rule example # a rule for encoding OWL transitive properties in RDL $OWL_Transitive_Property ?p ?x ?p ?y ?y ?p ?z -> ?x ?p ?z
    Since:
    JDK 1.5
    See Also:
    http://www.w3.org/TR/rdf-testcases/, Rule, ForwardChainer

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      protected java.util.ArrayList<Rule> allRules
      a hash set of all rules known to RuleStore
      protected java.util.Map<int[],Proxy> equivalentClauses
      a data structure that maps "equivalent" LHS clauses (even across rules) to binding tables (plus additional info), coming from the index
      boolean exitOnError
      a constant that controls whether the system is terminated in case an invalid tuple, test, or action is read in (exit code = 1); a similar variable exists in class TupleStore
      protected int lineNo
      current line number; make it a global field, since otherwise too many methods need to be extended by a further argument
      int maxNoOfArgs
      this constant is used to create the right number of index tables; note that the value of this constant has an effect on the index data structure; the larger the number, the more tables are created; reasonable values seem to be 3 (RDF triple), 4, or 5; a similar variable exists in class TupleStore
      int minNoOfArgs
      it seems reasonable to have tuples of at least length 1; a similar variable exists in class TupleStore
      protected Namespace namespace
      a namespace object used to expand short form namespaces into full forms
      private java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Integer,java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer>> proxyIdToFunctionalIds
      new for each rule object; represents a mapping from proxies for relational variabels to their functional counterparts; even non-complex relational variables are represented here through singleton lists
      boolean rdfCheck
      when tuples are read in, this variable decides whether tuples are compliant with what RDF requests, viz., that the first argument is either an URI or a blank node, and that the second arg is a URI
      private java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Integer> relationalVarToId
      only for internal use during the relational variable to id assignment;
      private static int RELVAR_OFFSET
      only for internal use during the relational variable to id assignment
      boolean reorderAntecedent 
      private RuleComparator ruleComparator
      the private rule comparator that is used by sortRules()
      protected TupleStore tupleStore
      a TupleStore object used to interface rule tuples with the initial base tuples
      static int UNBOUND
      since constants (or literals = URIs or XSD atoms) are assigned positive ints as representatives, 0 (zero) can be used at certain places to indicate that a variable is unbound or its value is not of interest (as used in predicate NoValue)
      private int varCounter
      only for internal use during functional+relational variable-to-id assignment
      private java.util.HashMap<java.lang.String,java.lang.Integer> varToId
      only for internal use during functional variable to id assignment (I have skipped the prefix "functional" for this field name); note: we do not need an inverse table; note: there exists a similar mapping objectToId for constants (to positive ints) in class TupleStore that is independent of the rules addressed here
      boolean verbose
      a constant that controls whether a warning is printed in case an invalid tuple is read in; a similar variable exists in class TupleStore

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      private boolean checkRuleSeparator(Rule rule, boolean anteOK)
      in case anteOK == false, the rule reader has NOT seen the LHS/RHS rule separator
      private void computeAmalgamation(Rule rule)
      determines which of the LHS clauses will go together during global LHS match through the use of join(); note that inequality constraints (as well as general constraints) also need to be considered here, e.g., ?x
      private void computeClusters(java.util.ArrayList<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer>> positions, java.util.ArrayList<java.util.HashSet<java.lang.Integer>> variables, Rule rule)
      bundles information that belongs to a cluster of dependent LHS clauses; e.g., list of LHS clauses, set of proper LHS variables, applicable list of var-var and list of var-const ineqs; the remaining applicable (RHS) in-eqs for the mega cluster are also determined here; note that the binding table that arises from joins of local tables are also stored here
      RuleStore copyRuleStore(Namespace namespace, TupleStore tupleStore)
      returns a copy of the rule store that can be used to generate "choice points, e.g., during reasoning, as is used by ForwardChainer
      private void createLocalTables(Rule rule)
      assigns a local Table object to each LHS clause of a rule structural equivalent clauses, e.g., or ; however, should be treated differently, since this pattern enforces identity at first and third position; if a pattern variable is furthermore a don't care variable, the corresponding pattern should not be identified with structural identical patterns not containing don't cares! across different rules, we will share the same local binding and delta table, even though the Table container are different; equivalence is represented by encoding a sequence of constants and variable encodings
      private boolean evaluateActions(Rule rule, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> actions)
      actions are assumed to be of the following form: = functionName { | | }^*
      private boolean evaluateInEqConstraint(Rule rule, java.lang.String line)
      inequality constraints are of the form ?var != ?var2 ?var != uri ?var != atom note the space around "!="
      private boolean evaluatePredicate(Rule rule, java.lang.String line)
      general predicates are of the form { | | | "*" }^* note the special form of variables for the post-HFCv6.xx version of RDL ::= "?" | "??" | "??(" ^{2..*} ")"
      private boolean evaluateTests(Rule rule, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> tests)
      transforms in-eqs and predicates to internal form
      private void generateAction(java.lang.String varname, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> tuple, int eqrel, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> actions, java.lang.String rulename) 
      private java.lang.String generateNewVariableName() 
      private void generateTest(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> tuple, int eqrel, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> tests, java.lang.String rulename) 
      private java.lang.Integer getFunId(java.lang.Integer relvar)
      obtains the id of the corresponding functional variable, given the relational variable id; note: I do NOT check whether there is such a functional var key in this.varToId
      private java.lang.Integer getFunId(java.lang.String relvar)
      obtains the id of the corresponding functional variable, given the relational variable name; note: I do NOT check whether there is such a functional var key in this.varToId
      private boolean handleSpecialVariables(Rule rule)
      stores the don't care variables (LHS) and the blank node introducing variables of the RHS in the rule object
      private int[] internalizeTuple(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> stringTuple)
      internalizeTuple() maps array lists of strings to int arrays of unique ints; positive ints (incl.
      static boolean isComplexRelationalVariable(java.lang.String literal)
      complex relational variables start with "??(" example: ??(subj obj)
      static boolean isFunctionalVariable(int id)
      "ordinary" functional variables
      static boolean isFunctionalVariable(java.lang.String literal)
      characterize "ordinary" functional variables
      static boolean isRelationalVariable(int id)
      relational variables (like functional ones) are assigned negative ints, smaller than RuleStore.RELVAR_OFFSET -- since a relational variable is associated with a functional variable from the LHS of a rule, its id is definded as id(??var) := RELVAR_OFFSET - id(?var)
      static boolean isRelationalVariable(java.lang.String literal)
      external representation: relational variables start with the "??" prefix
      boolean isValidTuple(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> stringTuple)
      checks whether a tuple of proper length as specified by this.minNoOfArgs and this.maxNoOfArgs; also checks whether the arguments of a _rule_ tuple are of the right "kind": arg 1: URI or variable arg 2: URI or variable arg 3, 4, ...
      static boolean isVariable(int id)
      internal representation: variables (both functional and relational) are represented by negative numbers
      static boolean isVariable(java.lang.String literal)
      external representation: variables start with the '?' character
      private boolean makeAntecedent(java.util.ArrayList<int[]> ante, Rule rule)
      extends a rule object by its internal representation of the antecedent; checks for various potential errors
      private boolean makeConsequent(java.util.ArrayList<int[]> cons, Rule rule)
      extends a rule object by its internal representation of the consequent; checks for various potential errors; internally records LHS only one time occuring variables (don't cares) and free RHS only variables (that will lead to introduction of blank nodes during rule application); finally enters the final rule object into the set of all rules
      protected int[] makeTuple(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> tuple)
      generates a tuple from a textual tokenized representation; checks for various potential errors and translates the external into an internal representation
      private boolean parseComplexVariable(java.lang.String prefix, java.util.StringTokenizer st, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer> args, java.lang.String rulename)
      parses complex relational variable names and updates the corresponding mappings; note: the string tokenizer is already freed from the "??(" prefix of a complex relational variable name, such as "??(subj obj)" NOTE: no more than 9 variable names should be involved in a complex relational variable
      private java.lang.String parseUriOrAtom(java.lang.String arg)
      parses a URI or an XSD atom and returns its cannonical form; note: blank nodes are NOT allowed to be directly specified, as they are anonymous individuals having no real name!
      private java.lang.String readActions(java.io.BufferedReader br, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> actions)
      read in all actions directly following "@action" for later evaluation
      protected java.util.ArrayList<Rule> readRules(java.lang.String filename)
      some of the checks that are performed during a rule file is read in: + check that antecedent and consequent consist of at least one tuple + output warning for unused variables (introduced on LHS, not used on RHS) -- encode don't care variables + output warning for unbound variables (not introduced on LHS, used on RHS) -- encode introduction of a fresh new individual + output warning for URIs & XSD atoms that are not mentioned in the initial fact base
      private java.lang.String readTests(java.io.BufferedReader br, java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> tests)
      read in all tests directly following "@test" for later evaluation
      private void reorderAntecedent(Rule rule)
      reorders the antecedent of a rule according to the heuristic implemented by the comparator
      private boolean sayItLoud(int lineNo, java.lang.String message)
      at several places, messages were output depending on this.exitOnError and this.verbose -- unify this in this special private method; perhaps will be replaced by Apache's log4j
      private boolean sayItLoud(java.lang.String rulename, java.lang.String message) 
      void sortRules()
      applies Collections.sort() to the set of all rules, destructively sorting this.allRules, using the instance this.ruleComparator from this rule store sortRules() is a public method, so that it can be applied even at runtime
      void writeRules(java.lang.String filename)
      a simple version that writes all rules from the rule store to a file using the external representation

        public static final int UNBOUND
        since constants (or literals = URIs or XSD atoms) are assigned positive ints as representatives, 0 (zero) can be used at certain places to indicate that a variable is unbound or its value is not of interest (as used in predicate NoValue)

      • isRelationalVariable

        public static boolean isRelationalVariable(int id)
        relational variables (like functional ones) are assigned negative ints, smaller than RuleStore.RELVAR_OFFSET -- since a relational variable is associated with a functional variable from the LHS of a rule, its id is definded as id(??var) := RELVAR_OFFSET - id(?var)

        == -1000000000, == -2147483648

        private boolean makeConsequent(java.util.ArrayList<int[]> cons,
                     Rule rule)
        extends a rule object by its internal representation of the consequent; checks for various potential errors; internally records LHS only one time occuring variables (don't cares) and free RHS only variables (that will lead to introduction of blank nodes during rule application); finally enters the final rule object into the set of all rules

      • reorderAntecedent

        private void reorderAntecedent(Rule rule)
        reorders the antecedent of a rule according to the heuristic implemented by the comparator
        See Also:
        ClauseComparator

      • computeAmalgamation

        private void computeAmalgamation(Rule rule)
        determines which of the LHS clauses will go together during global LHS match through the use of join(); note that inequality constraints (as well as general constraints) also need to be considered here, e.g., ?x

        ?_1, ?_2 ?y, ?x != ?y -> ... usually, one will have independent clusters of LHS clauses (instead of having only one); further examples: ?a

        ?b, ?c ?d, ?e ?f, ?a ?c ?e -> ... ?q ?c, ?r ?p, ?r ?c, ?i ?p ?q -> ... NOTE: at the moment, computeAmalgamation() does NOT take in-eqs, tests, and actions into account, thus the LHS clusters need to be merged into a mega cluster in ForwardChainer.prepareInstantiation() in order to apply restrict() (for ineqs and predicates) and to access information properly (for actions)

      • computeClusters

        private void computeClusters(java.util.ArrayList<java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.Integer>> positions,
                   java.util.ArrayList<java.util.HashSet<java.lang.Integer>> variables,
                   Rule rule)
        bundles information that belongs to a cluster of dependent LHS clauses; e.g., list of LHS clauses, set of proper LHS variables, applicable list of var-var and list of var-const ineqs; the remaining applicable (RHS) in-eqs for the mega cluster are also determined here; note that the binding table that arises from joins of local tables are also stored here

      • handleSpecialVariables

        private boolean handleSpecialVariables(Rule rule)
        stores the don't care variables (LHS) and the blank node introducing variables of the RHS in the rule object

      • isValidTuple

        public boolean isValidTuple(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> stringTuple)
        checks whether a tuple of proper length as specified by this.minNoOfArgs and this.maxNoOfArgs; also checks whether the arguments of a _rule_ tuple are of the right "kind": arg 1: URI or variable arg 2: URI or variable arg 3, 4, ... : URI, variable, or XSD atom NOTE: no blank nodes are allowed in rule tuples (contrary to ground tuples) finally check whether in case of a XSD atom, the atom is compatible with the specified XSD type ***** NOT IMPLEMENTED YET ***** depending on this.verbose and this.exitOnError, the method is silent, outputs a warning, or exit the process
        See Also:
        TupleStore.isValidTuple(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String>, int)

      • makeTuple

        protected int[] makeTuple(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> tuple)
        generates a tuple from a textual tokenized representation; checks for various potential errors and translates the external into an internal representation

      • internalizeTuple

        private int[] internalizeTuple(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> stringTuple)
        internalizeTuple() maps array lists of strings to int arrays of unique ints; positive ints (incl. 0) indicate (global) URIs and (global) XSD atoms, whereas negative numbers are reserved for variables, treated locally

      • createLocalTables

        private void createLocalTables(Rule rule)
        assigns a local Table object to each LHS clause of a rule structural equivalent clauses, e.g., or ; however, should be treated differently, since this pattern enforces identity at first and third position; if a pattern variable is furthermore a don't care variable, the corresponding pattern should not be identified with structural identical patterns not containing don't cares! across different rules, we will share the same local binding and delta table, even though the Table container are different; equivalence is represented by encoding a sequence of constants and variable encodings
        See Also:
        Table

      • readRules

        protected java.util.ArrayList<Rule> readRules(java.lang.String filename)
        some of the checks that are performed during a rule file is read in: + check that antecedent and consequent consist of at least one tuple + output warning for unused variables (introduced on LHS, not used on RHS) -- encode don't care variables + output warning for unbound variables (not introduced on LHS, used on RHS) -- encode introduction of a fresh new individual + output warning for URIs & XSD atoms that are not mentioned in the initial fact base

        public void sortRules()

        public RuleStore copyRuleStore(Namespace namespace,
                      TupleStore tupleStore)
        returns a copy of the rule store that can be used to generate "choice points, e.g., during reasoning, as is used by ForwardChainer
        See Also:
        de.dfki.lt.hfc.ForwardChainer.copyForwardChainer()
